text: Welcome to my channel, The English Grammar Doctor. Have you ever felt like nobody understands your heart? Have you ever looked at the stars and felt
something you can't explain? Today, I will tell you a story that teaches us how to see with the heart, not with the
eyes. It's called the little prince, and it will help you learn English in a way that also helps you understand life.
Tell me in the comments, do you believe children see the world better than adults? Chapter one hat. When I was 6 years old, I saw a picture in a book.
The picture was of a big snake. The snake ate a whole animal. The book said, "Snakes eat the animal and then sleep
for 6 months." I looked at the picture.
I thought it was very interesting. I like to imagine life in the jungle. I wanted to draw something too. So I made my first drawing. In my drawing, the
snake ate an elephant. The shape was long and round. I showed my picture to adults. I asked them, "Does this picture
scare you?" But they said, "Why should we be scared of a hat?" I was confused.
My drawing was not a hat. It was a snake who ate an elephant. But adults did not see it. They only saw a hat. I wanted to
help them understand. So, I made another drawing. In this picture, I drew the inside of the snake. You could see the
elephant inside. I called this picture number two. But the adults did not care.
They told me to stop drawing. They said it was better to study geography, math, history, and grammar. I was very sad. I
stopped drawing. I wanted to be an artist, but the adults didn't understand my pictures. So I listened to them. I
chose another job. I became a pilot. I flew planes. I flew in many countries. I saw many places. I met many people. I
had to learn geography. It helped me fly my plane in the right direction. Even after many years, I still met many adults. I talked to them. But I saw
something. Most adults were serious.
They talked about numbers and work. They didn't talk about stars or forests or love. When I met an adult who seemed
normal, I showed them my old picture.
Picture number one. I always kept it with me. I wanted to see if the person could really understand something deep.
But every time the person said, "It's a hat." Then I knew that this person was not someone I could talk to. I did not
speak about big snakes or stars. I just talked about simple things like money, golf or bridges. And then the adult was
happy because I talked like an adult, like a reasonable man. So for many years, I lived alone. I didn't have anyone to really talk to. I kept my
thoughts inside. But one day everything changed. I was flying over the desert.
Suddenly my plane had a problem.
Something in the engine broke. I was alone. There was no mechanic with me. no other person. I had to fix the plane by
myself. It was very difficult. I was in the Sahara Desert. There were no people, no houses, no roads, just sand. I only
had a little water, enough for one week.
I had to work fast. If I didn't fix the plane, I could die. I felt scared. I was alone in the middle of the desert. That
night, I slept on the sand. It was very quiet. I was far from everything, a thousand miles away from any city or village. It felt like I was on another
planet. I closed my eyes and slept. I didn't know that my life was going to change forever. The next morning, chapter 2. Sheep. The sun was just
rising. I was still sleeping on the sand. I was alone in the big desert.
There was no village, no road, no house.
I was more alone than a man in a small boat in the middle of the ocean. But then something very strange happened. A
quiet voice woke me up. It said, "Please draw me a sheep." I opened my eyes quickly. I was shocked. I looked around
and I saw a little boy, a very small boy. He had golden hair. He was standing in front of me. He looked calm. He
didn't look scared. He didn't look lost.
He was just standing there and looking at me. He said again, "Draw me a sheep." His voice was soft. His eyes were serious. I stared at him. I was a
thousand miles away from any person. I didn't understand. I asked him, "What are you doing here?" But he didn't answer my question. He only said, "Draw
me a sheep." I felt surprised, but I didn't know why.
Something in his face was different. It was not like other people. I wanted to say more, but I remembered. I am not an
artist. I stopped drawing when I was six. I could only draw two things. A snake from the outside and a snake from the inside. So, I showed him my old
picture, the one that looked like a hat.
He looked at it and said, "No, no, no. I don't want a snake who ate an elephant.
That's too scary. And an elephant is too big. I want a sheep. Where I live, everything is very small. So I tried again. I drew a sheep. He looked at it
and said, "This sheep looks very sick. I don't want a sick sheep." So I drew another one. He said, "This one has horns. That's not a sheep. That's a
ram." I tried again. He said, "This sheep is too old. I want a young sheep that can live a long time. I didn't know
what to do. I was tired. I wanted to fix my engine. So, I quickly drew a small box. I said, "This is a box. Your sheep
is inside the box." He looked at the box for a moment. Then his face lit up. He was very happy. He said, "Yes, this is
perfect. This is just what I wanted. Do you think this sheep will need a lot of grass?" I said, "Why do you ask?" He answered, "Because where I live
everything is very small." I smiled and said, "Don't worry. I gave you a very small sheep." He looked at the picture
again and said, "It's sleeping now." And I looked at him. I didn't understand what was happening, but I knew this moment was special. I felt something
warm in my heart. That is how I met the little prince. Chapter 3. Planet I didn't know where the little prince came
from, but I wanted to know. He didn't answer questions directly. He asked many questions, but he almost never answered
mine. Still, little by little, I started to understand him. He said something one day that helped me learn more. He looked
at my airplane and said, "What is this thing?" I told him, "It's not just a thing. It's my plane. It flies in the
sky. I felt a little proud when I said that. He looked at me and asked, "Oh, you fell from the sky?" "Yes," I answered. He laughed a soft, clear
laugh. He said, "So, you also came from the sky like me?" "That made me stop.
That sentence like me was important. It was different. It was a clue." I asked quickly, "Do you come from another planet?" But he didn't answer.
He just looked down and nodded a little.
Then he looked again at my plane and said, "Of course, with that thing, you couldn't have come very far. He became
quiet again. He took the picture of the box with the sheep from his pocket. He looked at it for a long time. He was
thinking, I could see it." Then I asked him very gently, "Where do you come from? Where's your home? Where do you want to take the sheep?" He didn't
answer at once, but then he said, "It's good that the sheep has a box. At night, it can be its house." I said, "Yes, of
course, and I will also give you a rope.
You can tie the sheep during the day." But the little prince looked shocked.
Tie the sheep? That's funny. I said, "If you don't tie the sheep, it will run away. It will get lost." The little prince laughed again. A sweet, soft
laugh. "Where would it go?" he said.
"Anywhere.
It could walk left or right or straight." He looked down again and said quietly. "It's okay. Where I live, everything is so small. The sheep can't
go far." And when he said that, I understood something very important. His planet was very small. It was no bigger than a house. But that was not
surprising. I already knew about very small planets. Scientists sometimes find them with big telescopes. They don't
give them names, just numbers. They call them things like asteroid 3-251.
And now I was sure the little prince came from one of those small planets.
Maybe the one called asteroid B612.
Chapter 4. Asteroid. I believe the little prince came from a small planet called asteroid B612.
This planet was seen only once by a man with a telescope. It was a Turkish scientist. He saw it in the year 1909.
He told other scientists about it at a big meeting, but no one believed him.
Why? Because he wore Turkish clothes. He looked different. Adults are like that.
They don't believe the truth if it doesn't look the way they want. Many years later, the same man spoke again, but this time he wore European clothes.
He looked normal. And now everyone believed him. That is how adults think.
It's strange, but it happens often. I'm telling you all this because adults love numbers. They don't care about feelings
or beauty. When you tell them, "I met a friend," they ask, "How old is he? How many brothers does he have? How much
does he weigh? How much money does his father make?" If you say, "He has a nice voice, he likes butterflies, he loves to
laugh," they don't listen. They only care about numbers. They think numbers are more real than love or laughter. If
you say, "I saw a red house with flowers in the window and birds on the roof," they don't understand. But if you say,
"I saw a house that cost $100,000." Then they say, "Wow, that's a beautiful house." This is how they think. So when
I tell them about the little prince, I don't say, "He laughed and wanted a sheep." They won't care. But if I say he came from asteroid B612,
then they listen. Then they believe. But we who understand life, we don't care about numbers. We like stories. We know
that stories tell the truth better than facts. So I tell this story like a fairy tale. I say once upon a time there was a
little prince. He lived on a small planet. He had a flower and he was looking for a friend. If you understand what that means, then this story is for
you. Chapter 5. Elephants.
It has been six years since I met the little prince. But when I think about our time together, I still feel something deep inside my heart. I
remember each word, each drawing, and each quiet moment in the desert. I don't want to forget any of it. That's why I
am telling you this story now. I want to keep it safe. I want to keep the little prince alive in my memory. Because when
we forget a friend, it is very sad and not everyone has a real friend. So I bought some pencils and started drawing again. Even though I had not drawn
anything since I was a child, I try to make my drawings look true, but it is not easy. Sometimes the little prince
looks too tall, sometimes too short. I don't even know if I got the color of his clothes right, but I try my best. I
hope you can forgive my mistakes. The little prince never explained much. He thought I could understand everything
like him, but I couldn't. Maybe because I was already becoming like the adults.
Maybe I was already old. Every day I learned something new about his planet.
He didn't tell me everything at once. He told me little by little when something reminded him of his past.
On the third day, I learned about the danger of baobobs. It was during a conversation about sheep. He asked me, "Is it true that sheep eat little
bushes?" I said, "Yes, of course." He said, "Ah, I'm glad." I didn't understand why this was important. Then he added, "So they also eat baobobs."
Now I was surprised. I told him, "Baoabs are not like little bushes. Baababs are very big trees. They are as big as
churches. Even if you had a group of nine elephants, they could not eat a single baobab." I laughed when I said this. nine elephants on a tiny planet.
They would have to stand on each other.
The little prince laughed too. But then he became serious again. He said something very important. Before baobobabs grow big, they are small, very
small. And then I understood. Baababs start as small seeds. They are like little plants at first, but if you don't pull them out early, they grow fast.
Then they become too strong. Their roots go deep into the ground. On the little prince's planet, the ground is very
small. If too many baobobs grow, they can break the whole planet. Their roots can tear the planet into pieces. That's
why the prince wanted a sheep. He needed it to eat the small bushes before they became dangerous trees. I could now
imagine the life of the little prince.
Every morning he would wake up, clean his volcanoes, and look for small baobob plants. Then he would pull them out
quickly before they could grow. It was like a daily duty, a quiet fight against disaster. He said, "It's a question of
discipline. Sometimes there are good plants and sometimes there are bad ones, but the seeds look the same. You have to
watch them carefully. When you see a bad one growing, you must remove it immediately.
This lesson touched me deeply. I thought about our world. Maybe we also have baobobs. Bad habits, bad thoughts, bad
feelings. If we don't stop them early, they grow and take over our lives. If we let anger, jealousy, or lies grow, they
can destroy everything, just like the baobabs on the prince's planet. But if we are careful, if we take time each day
to clean our hearts, then we are safe.
We need our own discipline, too. The little prince asked me to draw a picture of the baobabs for children. He said,
"Sometimes children wait too long. Then it's too late." He was right. When a baobab is big, it's hard to remove.
That's why I made a serious drawing of three huge baobobs. Their roots are deep. They are heavy and strong. I wanted this picture to be a warning, a
simple but important message. Pull the baobobs when they are small. The prince spoke quietly that day. He looked into
the sky as he talked. I could see that he wasn't just speaking about trees. He was thinking about his planet, his flower, and maybe about something he
didn't say. And I was listening, not just with my ears, but with my heart.
Chapter 6.
Trees.
After learning about the Baobabs, I started to understand more about the little prince's planet. He did not tell
me everything at once. He spoke in short sentences, but each sentence had meaning. Each little word helped me see
his world more clearly. I saw that his planet was small but full of life. It had volcanoes, sunsets, and seeds. There
were many seeds in the ground, some good and some bad. And that is how I began to understand about the trees. He told me
that on his planet, just like on earth, seeds fall into the ground. The ground doesn't choose the seed. It accepts all
seeds, good ones and bad ones. Then the seed sleeps. It sleeps deep in the soil, sometimes for a long time. But one day
it wakes up. Slowly the seed begins to grow.
At first the plant is very small. You cannot tell what kind of plant it is. It might be a rose. It might be a weed. It might be something beautiful or
something dangerous. The little prince said that this is the important moment.
When the plant is small, it is easy to pull out. But when it grows, it becomes harder. Some plants grow fast, some grow
slowly. But if the plant is bad and you don't pull it out soon, it becomes a big problem. That is what happens with
baobobs. At first they look like all the other little plants. You don't know they are baobobs. You think they are just
small leaves. But then they grow. They grow tall. Their roots go deep. Their trunks become thick. If you wait too long, it is too late. They become too
strong. And they can break your planet.
I listened carefully and I started thinking. This is not just about trees.
It is about everything in life. A small bad thing can become a big problem. If you fix it early, it's easy. But if you
wait, it becomes very hard. A small lie, a little anger, a bit of laziness. If you don't stop it when it's small, it
grows. It spreads. It takes your joy. It breaks your heart. Just like Beaabs break a planet.
I looked at the little prince and I understood.
His planet was like his heart. He had to take care of it. Every morning he watched it. Every day he worked to keep
it safe and that's how he lived. He told me that some days it was hard to get up.
Some days he felt lazy. But he said it is a question of discipline. Even if he was tired, he would get up. He would check his planet. He would look for
small baobobs. He would pull them out before they grew big. It is easy, he said. But you must do it every day. I thought about my own life. I thought
about my thoughts, my habits, my heart.
Maybe I had my own baobobs.
Maybe we all do. We all have small things inside us. Jealousy, fear, sadness. If we are not careful, they grow. They take space. They become hard
to remove. But if we see them early, we can pull them out. We can be free.
The little prince didn't say much more.
He looked up at the stars. I stayed quiet, too. There was nothing more to say. I just looked at him. His face was calm. He was small, but he had a big
heart. He was serious, but kind. He was just a boy, but also more than a boy. I didn't know everything about his planet,
but I knew one thing. It was small. It was fragile. And it was beautiful, just like a heart.
Chapter 7. Sun. The little prince loved the sun. And he told me this one morning while we were sitting in the sand. He
said, "On my planet, I can see the sunset many times a day." I looked at him and smiled. He was not joking. He really meant it. He said, "All I have to
do is move my chair a little. Then I can see the sun go down again. I thought that was beautiful. On Earth, we have to
wait the whole day for one sunset." But the little prince could watch many. He told me one time he watched the sunset
44 times. I was surprised and I asked him why did you watch it so many times.
He looked at me and said because I was very sad. That touched my heart.
Sometimes when we are sad we look at beautiful things. We want to feel peace.
The little prince didn't cry. He didn't talk much. But he watched the sunset again and again. He sat and waited. He
moved his chair. He looked at the sky and he felt the warm orange light. It gave him comfort. It gave him hope.
Maybe he was thinking of home or maybe of someone he loved. I didn't ask. I just listened. The sun was special to
him. He said it made him feel calm. It made his small planet feel big. When the light touched the ground, everything
looked golden. He said, "The sun helps flowers. The sun wakes me up. The sun makes me feel alive." I looked at his face. It was soft and
quiet. He wasn't just talking about the sun in the sky. He was talking about something deeper. The sun in his heart.
The light that gives you strength when you are tired. The warmth that makes you smile even when you are alone.
I remembered my own childhood. I also loved the sunset. I used to sit on the roof of our house. I waited for the
light to change. The sky turned yellow, then orange, then pink, then purple.
Then the stars came out. It always felt like magic. I never told anyone how much I loved it. But when the little prince
spoke, I remembered that feeling. I remembered the silence, the soft wind, the slow fading of the day. And I understood him better. He said, "People
on your planet are always busy. They forget to look at the sun." He was right. We run from place to place. We look at our phones. We think about work,
money, problems, but we forget the sky.
We forget the light. We forget the joy of simple things like a sunset. The little prince taught me something important. He taught me that looking at
the sun is also a way of feeling, a way of remembering, a way of healing. He didn't have much, just a tiny planet, a
flower, and a chair. But he had the sun, and he used it. He watched it with love, with care, with heart.
That day in the desert, we both looked at the sunset. The sky was wide. The colors changed slowly. No words were needed.
The little prince didn't speak. He just watched. And I watched with him. In that moment, we were both quiet. We were both
human. We were both full of something very old and very deep. When the sun finally disappeared, he looked at me. He
said, "The sun always goes down, but it also comes back." And I knew he was not just talking about the sun.
Chapter 8. Flower.
One day, the little prince told me about a flower. His voice became soft when he spoke about her. His eyes looked far
away, as if he was back on his planet again. he said. One morning a new flower appeared. She came slowly. The seed had
slept in the ground for a long time.
Then one day it woke up. The flower grew inside a bud. She took her time. She wanted to be perfect. She prepared herself quietly. She chose her colors
carefully. She wanted her petals to be just right. And finally, one morning, just as the sun rose, she opened. The little prince was amazed.
She was beautiful. She was soft. She was full of color and light. He had never seen anything like her. All the other
flowers on his planet were simple. But this one was different. She was proud.
She was delicate. She was special. At first, the little prince didn't understand her. She started speaking in a slow and graceful voice. She said, "I
just woke up. I'm sorry. My hair is messy." She had a kind of pride, but it was not cruel. It was soft and quiet.
She wanted to be loved. The little prince said, "You are very beautiful." And she smiled. But then she said, "Do
you have a screen to protect me from the wind?" The little prince didn't know. He had never taken care of a flower like
this before. He felt shy. He didn't know what to do. Then she asked, "And what about breakfast? Can you bring me
something?" The little prince ran to get water. He tried his best. He brought her a glass dome to protect her from the
cold. He gave her love. But sometimes she said things that confused him. She talked about tigers. She talked about
her thorns. She tried to be strong, but she was not. She was soft inside. She was afraid, and she didn't know how to say, "I love you."
The little prince became sad. He didn't understand her words. He didn't see the love hidden behind her pride. He thought
she didn't care about him. He felt alone. He started to feel unhappy on his planet. That's when he decided to leave.
He said to me, "I didn't understand flowers then. I was too young to understand love." When he left, he looked at her one last time. She said,
"I was wrong. I didn't know how to show my feelings. I love you, but you didn't understand me. And I didn't understand
you. That is my fault. Please go be free. Try to be happy." She was not proud anymore. She was gentle. She didn't cry. She didn't ask him to stay.
She let him go. That is true love.
Letting someone go if they need to. The little prince was surprised. He didn't expect that. She looked beautiful in the
morning light. The wind touched her petals. She stood quietly in the breeze.
The little prince didn't want to leave, but he had already decided. He wanted to see other places. He wanted to learn.
And now he carried her in his heart. As he told me this story, he looked at the sky. His voice was low. He missed her. I
could feel it. He didn't say the word love, but it was there in every sentence, in every pause, in every look.
He had loved that flower, and maybe she had loved him, too. But sometimes when we are young, we don't know how to show
it. And that is why the little prince left his planet. Not because he stopped caring, but because he wanted to understand.
Chapter nine. Glass. The little prince stayed with the flower for some time before he left his planet. But during those days, things were not easy. The
flower, who had once opened so gently, became difficult. She asked many things.
She spoke in a strange way and slowly the little prince felt confused. She started to cough, he told me, looking
down at the sand. But I don't think she was really sick. I think she just wanted attention. He wasn't angry when he said
this. He was sad. The kind of sadness that comes when love feels too hard. The flower would say, "The night was cold.
You didn't cover me. I could die from this." or sometimes she would sigh and say, "You don't really care about me. If you did, you would never leave me
alone." The little prince didn't understand. He tried to help. He watered her every morning. He protected her with
a glass dome. He even cleaned around her so the wind wouldn't hurt her. But the more he tried, the more she complained.
And slowly, he felt tired. He loved her, but he didn't know how to show it. And she loved him, but she didn't know how
to say it in simple words. She was proud, he said softly. And I was too young to understand that pride hides pain. He told me she would say things
that hurt him, like, "You should have done this." Or, "Why don't you ever say kind things to me?" But he was quiet. He
didn't know how to say I love you with words.
So he gave her water. He brought her the glass cover. He showed love in his actions. But she wanted love in words.
One day the flower said, "I don't need the glass. I am strong. I can take care of myself." But she wasn't strong. She
was afraid. She just didn't want to seem weak. She didn't want him to see her soft heart. So she pretended to be brave. She said, "You can go if you
want." And the little prince thought she meant it. So he decided to leave. He prepared everything. He cleaned his
volcanoes. He pulled out the last baobab shoots. He put his planet in order. And then he looked at the flower. She was
standing in the wind looking at the sky.
He said goodbye. She didn't move. Then she said, "I was wrong. I'm sorry. I want you to be happy. I love you.
He was surprised. Her voice was different, soft, honest. She was not coughing anymore and she was not complaining. She was just quiet. He
almost didn't leave. But something inside told him it was time. He had to go. He had to learn more. Maybe one day
he could come back. He looked at her one last time.
He wanted to remember her like this, calm, peaceful, standing in the sun. He put the glass dome over her gently, like a kiss.
She didn't want me to see her cry, he said. Flowers are so mysterious.
I said nothing. I just listened because I understood. Sometimes we love people, but we don't know how to show it.
Sometimes we wait too long to say I'm sorry or I care. And sometimes when we finally say it, the person is already
leaving. But the little prince didn't hate the flower. He carried her in his heart. Even when he left, even as he traveled to other planets, even as he
sat beside me in the desert telling this story, she was still with him. Chapter 10. volcanoes.
Before the little prince left his planet, he did something important. He cleaned his volcanoes. He told me about it with care in his voice. I had three
volcanoes on my planet, he said. Two were active, one was not, but I cleaned all of them. He used a small rake. He
cleaned around the top of each volcano.
He made sure nothing blocked them. He said, "When volcanoes are clean, they burn gently. They don't explode." He
smiled. "It's like brushing your teeth.
If you do it every day, you stay healthy." I listened. I could see him, a small boy with golden hair, standing on
his tiny planet, cleaning his volcanoes with love. It was not a big job, but it was his job, and he did it with care.
Even the volcano that didn't erupt, the sleeping one, he cleaned that too. He said, "You never know. Maybe one day it
will wake up." That touched me. How many things in life do we leave because they are quiet, because they are silent?
But the little prince didn't forget anything. He didn't say, "This one is useless." He said, "This one might wake up someday." And so he cared for it,
too. I thought about my own life. How many things I forgot to clean. Not just rooms or dishes, but friendships, promises, dreams. Some of them were
quiet, like the third volcano sleeping, but still there, still waiting. The little prince understood something deep.
He knew that love means care, even for small things, even for silent things. He didn't rush. He didn't skip steps. He
cleaned each volcano with patience. He looked around his planet slowly. It was his home and he wanted to leave it clean. Then he pulled out the last
baobab shoots. Baababs are bad plants.
If you let them grow, they become huge.
They break the planet. But when they are small, you can remove them easily. So the little prince checked his ground. He
pulled each one carefully. He said, "Sometimes bad things grow quietly. If you wait too long, they get too big.
Then it's hard to stop them." He looked serious when he said this. I thought of bad habits, angry thoughts, sadness.
All these things are like baobobs.
If you don't watch them, they grow. If you don't act early, they take over. The little prince knew this and that's why
he checked every day, cleaning his volcanoes, pulling the baobabs, saying goodbye to his flower. He told me it was
a peaceful morning. I did everything I always do. But I knew this time I would not come back soon. He didn't cry. He
didn't rush. He just did what he always did. That was his way of saying goodbye with action, with love. I asked him,
"Was it hard to leave?" He looked at me for a moment. Then he said, "Yes, but I wanted to understand things. I had to
go." That's when I realized sometimes we leave home not because we stop loving it, but because we want to understand it
better. We go far so we can see what it really means to us. And when we come back, we love it more. That morning before he left, the little prince gave
one last look at his planet. It was small. It had a flower, three volcanoes, and some stars above. But for him, it was the whole world. Then he stepped
into the wind and left.
Chapter 11. King.
After the little prince left his own planet, he began to visit other planets.
He wanted to learn. He wanted to meet new people. He wanted to understand grown-ups. The first planet he visited
was very small, but it was not empty. It had a king. The king was sitting on a big chair. He wore a purple robe and had
a crown on his head. He looked very serious. When he saw the little prince, he said, "Ah, a subject." His voice was loud, like a person who gives many
orders. The little prince looked around.
There was no one else, just the king.
The planet was too small for more than one person.
A subject? The little prince asked. But who do you rule? The king raised his chin. I rule over everything, he said.
Over this planet, over the stars, and even over you. The little prince was surprised. You rule the stars? Yes, the king said, "And they obey me. I give
orders, and they listen." The little prince wanted to see how powerful this king really was. So he asked, "Can you
order the sun to set?" The king looked confused. Then he answered carefully, "Yes, of course, but I must wait for the
right time." I only give orders that make sense. I order the sun to set. At sunset, the little prince laughed.
That's not a real order, then. But the king didn't laugh. He was serious. He believed he had great power. But really
he had no one to rule. He just liked giving orders. Then the king said, "Stay with me. I will make you a minister." "A
minister of what?" asked the little prince. "Of justice," the king said proudly. "But there is no one here," the little prince replied. "Then judge
yourself," the king said. "That is the hardest task. Judging others is easy, but judging yourself is real wisdom. The
